reviewText: I the actress portrayed the title character well, but I believe the story, enhanced would've been alot better for the mainstream audience. However, it goes well with my spooky but drama collection.

This is a dark and disturbing tale of a young girl from a distant disengaged family who under improbable circumstances meets and cares for an injured boy shot after being used a drug mule. In the course of doing so she uncovers a mystery and comes to know good and evil both in the world and herself.

This movie was great. It's intense and surreal and weird, and I couldn't stop watching it. They chose a film which looked like 70's stock, which added to the surreal nature. I might compare it to a Clockwork Orange. The acting is brilliant, especially since there's so little talking. I was surprised at the nudity but did not find it offensive.

Eerie Euro-Art film about drugs, love and death.
Excellent acting by the two young stars.
A strange Romeo and Juliet tale.
Highly recommended!

This film fails on several accounts. One is the sick Paula Vander Oest directing her own daughter Laurien Van den Broeck who was only 14 in a few sex scenes.

Other aspects of this film just don't make sense.

Claire is 14 and she freaks out when she has her first period and she obviously doesn't know what's happened and runs down to the family shed to hide. However, there she meents 'boy' played by Hunter Bussemaker who's been shot in the abdomen, and using her father's doctor's tools and books to look after him. So she's gone from being totally naive about her body to being able to perform surgery on him the next day.

Then the plot goes weirder. The two hit the road and become lovers.
